review_body: The High Line Hotel provides a cozy, clean, one of a kind experience. While the doors on the rooms are thin (not great for light sleepers), comfortable beds and beautiful furniture and architecture make up for it. The lobby truly sets the tone of the hotel with a coffee shop filled with young people and dogs. One of a kind hotel in Chelsea.

Beautiful refurbished building, with small lobby, often crowded with non guests and dogs. Rooms are clean, vary in size and have outstanding beds and linens. I have found the down bedding too hot, and they have changed it. There are no grips in the showers, and the very worn antique rugs present a tripping hazard. There is a coffee/snack bar but no restaurant. Also, no coffee maker in room, for obvious reason. Staff is friendly and helpful.

The High Line Hotel on 10th Avenue at 20th is absolute perfection! The rooms are cozy, quiet and comfortable. A tranquil radiance envelopes you upon entering the intimate lobby and continues throughout the hotel with it's numerous thoughtful touches and immaculate decor. This is no cookie cutter hotel, it is an intimate rest stop in the big city.
user_location: Washington, District of Columbia, United States

review_body: Our stay was only a short one, but we found the accommodation and service to be excellent, and it’s location close to the High Line and all the bars and restaurants in the area made it a perfect location to stay... and one we will use again

We loved the hotel’s ambience, the history, the friendliness. The staff, especially Emily and Xavier were so helpful and welcoming. The lobby/lounge has a wonderful relaxed atmosphere and is a great place to enjoy a coffee or a drink. The access to the High Line is so convenient and this area of New York is delightful to stay in.

The only con to this hotel was having to wait an additional hour past the check-in time for my room. Other than that I had a great experience. There's a great coffee shop inside the lobby, a wonderful outdoor restaurant with a fantastic brunch, right outside and the rooms are very nice. Well kept. Stayed July 2018.

An amazing hotel with a ton of character in Chelsea. Each room is uniquely decorated and the beds are comfortable. Oversized bar (not just airplane bottles) in each room. It was our second time visiting the High Line Hotel and it will not be our last. Dog friendly. Don't forget to walk the High Line up to Hudson Yards. Very cool place.

Absolutely loved this hotel! I stayed in a standard King room and it was so spacious. I loved the details included in the decor and the little things like a coloring book were such a treat. The staff is friendly and helpful, they were able to hold our luggage during the day and then called us as soon as our room was available. The bar is very nice too - wish I remembered the bartenders name but he was really cool and made the best toddy!! Great area within NYC as well. Easy to get to from Penn station, access to the high line and Chelsea Market, and lovely area to stroll through - especially during the holidays!

This hotel is a lovely boutique hotel that has nice sized rooms (for NYC and big-city standards). The room didn't have a closet but they do provide a rolling rack where you can hang your clothes, which is a nice touch. We had plenty of room to open our luggage on the floor and be able to walk around. There was even a desk in the room. My favorite part of this hotel was the magnificent coffee smell (and excellent coffee), the fact that there are always dogs in the lobby, and the lovely bar at night. Michael (the manager) is fantastic. Very nice person and also makes excellent drinks. I would recommend this hotel if you like boutique hotels and somewhere where you won't feel like too much of a tourist. Many locals seem to hang out here which is really nice because I love to experience places the way the locals do. If you're looking for a traditional hotel experience maybe this isn't the place for you because they don't have a traditional front desk. It was definitely a lovely experience though!

Perfect location, super staff and comfortable rooms. The coffee bar in the morning has lots of variety, then turning into a social bar in the evening that is dog friendly. I would not hesitate to book The High Line hotel again for my next visit.

Room 49 leaked. Drip, drip, drip, drip. Lots of street noise. Trucks backing up. Beep, beep, beep, beep... Bed and bedding were great. Towels were big, robes & slippers, warm room, great water pressure, hot water. No front desk. Couldn’t figure out who was or if there was hotel staff. No for man. No bell man. Experience similar to walking into a pub with an inn upstairs. Clean enough. I kept my slippers on. Not a great hotel experience. But I liked my room and I slept okay both nights I was there. Three blocks from Root studio made it convenient and walkable. Great area and very close to the high line. There’s an entrance half a block away. Cute desk, coloring book and bike map.

We had a great visit to NYC! The staff at the High Line Hotel were extremely helpful and very friendly. We were greeted each time they saw us and asked us about our activities and continued conversations from previous conversations like we were their only concern.Hospitality at its best.

Dog friendly hotel. Cozy lobby for drinks or breakfast with coffee and pastries. Comfortable room with large bathroom. Beautiful lines, towels and robes. Location of hotel is perfect for exploring Chelsea Market and Hudson Yards. And the High Line is just 2 blocks away. Can’t wait to return.

The Highline hotel is where it all began for me--one gorgeous summer day I did my usual morning routine having my own business, I worked out of the back of the highline hotel where they serve amazing coffee and there's a beautiful hidden garden with tables where you lose yourself and forget you're in NYC and feel like you're in Europe surrounded by gorgeous flowers and the historic building which is now the hotel but was a theological seminary. That morning changed my life as that is where I met my husband, who religiously stayed at that hotel, also his favorite, every time he was in town from CA visiting a friend.I sat next to him and that was the moment my life changed. Fast forward two years later and we are married and continue to go back to the Highline Hotel, a favorite not only because of our story but it truly is a treasure and the best hotel in NY; the rooms are large, comfortable and beautifully decorated all unique with personality and very charming. The beds are so comfortable and the staff is wonderful, friendly and we tell anyone who is visiting NYC to go to that hotel, and if they are not spending the night they must go to experience the magical hidden garden in the back while sipping some intelligensea coffee or tea.We're lucky as we also got to know the manager who is hands down the best hotel manager I've connected with and that place is run so great--he also carries that warmth and kindness that you feel when you enter the front doors.I can['t sing enough praise for this place that is very special to me, and it will make your trip extra special to experience it.

Unless you are travelling with a pet and need a pet-friendly hotel, this is not where you should stay during your time in New York. New York is known for its variety of options and trust me, there are plenty of better options than The High Line Hotel.To start, the hotel is deceiving. Because of its name and location, you are left with the impression that they are going to live up to the price tag they are asking. You would expect, for example, for the hotel to be clean at a minimum. You would also expect the hotel to be well managed and friendly. Unfortunately, they are neither clean nor accommodating. In fact, this is one of the strangest boutique hotel environments I've ever been in where everything just feels off from the smell to the vibe to the entire experience starting with even the check-in process. It was so bad that I ended up checking out of the hotel early even though I was charged a penalty fee. Plus, if you are looking for an evening of rest while you are on your trip that is free of barking, then steer way clear of The High Line Hotel.

This charming hotel is in the heart of the Chelsea district in Manhattan and the minute we walked in we felt at home. Our room was spacious and decorated with antiques and it was so clean that it sparkled! The delicious coffee bar in the lobby turned into a craft cocktail bar at night. We enjoyed using both of them and visiting with locals that lived in the neighborhood.

My experience at The High Line Hotel was phenomenal. Elizabeth (if I remember her name correctly), who checked me in, was extremely helpful and made my stay very enjoyable. The area is quaint and in close proximity to great food and the high line. The rooms were charming and the beds comfortable. Definitely will stay here again next time that I am visiting!

The High Line Hotel is my favorite spot to stay on the West Side of NYC.It's like a little bit Hogwarts with an elevated charm.The BEDS! I always sleep like a baby here.And I love strolling the neighborhood after long days at work.One of my favorite coffee shops is in the lobby and creates a warm family vibe with all the "locals" stopping in with their puppies. :) Can't wait to be back.

Only a couple of complaints. 1. When I checked in the key card marker was not working. My keys were delivered about 2 hours later.2. On the 2nd day of my stay my room was not cleaned during the day. I had to call guest services and request for my room to be cleaned once I returned from training at 4pm.

Great location. Beautiful, historic building; large, clean comfortable rooms and friendly staff. Great espresso in the lobby in the morning - nice bar in the evening. My favorite place to stay in the area!

This was tragic, from start to finish: street noise intolerable; felt like we'd booked a room in a kennel (dogs barking in the adjoining rooms most of the night); they charged our credit cards twice for one night stay; coffee was cold. Avoid!

The location and price can't be beat - right on the High Line and close to the Whitney. Unfortunately the hotel has turned its small lobby over to the neighbors with their dogs, small children and noise. Are they trying to be a coffee shop or hotel?

Great location, vibe, check in only negative is loud outside noise from construction. Everyone is very friendly and look to accommodate your needs from restaurants, to things to do in the city. Not too sure why TripAdvisor makes you write 200 words for a review but this run on sentence will satisfy the computer software so this review will be posted;)

staff does not take responsibility for what goes on at the hotel and treats patrons poorly. for instance, I tried to take a seat on one of the couches in lobby, and the staff standing there did nothing when another patron yelled at me his gf had that seat. They simply looked on, directly, without saying anything,

The profit center of this establishment is clearly it’s Intelligensia coffee bar. Locals were packed in the small lobby/coffee all day long. It was difficult to scoot by to get to the stairs/elevators. At $600-$700 per night, it felt like a hostel more than a hotel. There isn’t even a front desk. Very bad room acoustics—it sounded like another couple on our floor was having sex in our room. Room was large and reasonably clean, with the exception of dusty curtains.

The rooms are dirty and badly designed, and the hotel has no concern for customer satisfaction or service. There is no reception, room service and many times when we called we couldn’t even reach a person. We had a three day stay and the whole experience was awful. Will never stay again. Much better to spend the extra money and stay at the Bowery.

Like others have said, The High Line is more of a popular local coffee shop that rents rooms than a hotel. My guess is that it’s better in the summer when the coffee shop customers can sit outside but now the small area you might expect to be for guest to relax in is full of young people on their laptops. We tried to have a glass of wine before dinner and again, no place to sit. What makes it worse is that our room had no where to relax either. Only a very cool to look at but impossible to sit in antique love seat. We love quaint little coffee shops and we love quirky boutique hotels but this combination doesn’t work. I’d look elsewhere.

not a hotel in any way shape or form - i think i upset the staff buy booking a room and staying there - i thought it was a hotel but seems it was not - no room service , no service , no interest apart from taking my money - dont pay or stay

quirky, fun, friendly, super dog friendly oasis in Chelsea. Enjoyed every moment. Fabulous coffee at Intelligentsia in the lobby that folks were flocking to!Amazing location: High Line, Chelsea Market (crowded!!) Whitney Museum of American art. Artichoke Pizza.

We paid over $600/night at the hotel. It looks cute online but we had nothing but issues. The lobby is filled with non-guests having coffee with their dogs (I'm a dog lover); but we couldn't even make in through with our suitcases to check-in. Check-In? There is NO reservation desk. Just a cash register. No one to assist with baggage. When we got to our room it was on 10th Avenue. Noise and sirens all day and night long. There was no dresser or drawers anywhere to unpack. You can barely close the bathroom door. The bathroom is so small, they don't even have a towel rack. The waste basket had to be placed behind the toilet it was so small in there.No counter space either. The vent up above was caked with dust and debris. There was no filter. Wires were hanging down and the worst is it never shuts down. Try and sleep through that. The thermostat couldn't be adjusted. The walls inside were slanted like an attic and my husband hit his head twice. There is no bar, restaurant nor room service available. The final straw was we were in town for a vintage champagne event and brought back 2 vintage bottles (empty) with valuable labels that we purchased. They were in a bag on the desk. Yes, housekeeping threw them out. They are invaluable. Complained and they shrugged their shoulders. HORRIBLE!!!

Overall stay was nice but room cleanliness was not up to par. Shower did not drain and there were gross stains on the curtains near the bed that made us uncomfortable. Staff was very accommodating and friendly but wish the room was cleaner. We checked in late at night for one night only but had it been a longer stay we would have asked to move rooms or a refund.

The rooms that face 10th Ave can be a bit noisier naturally. The hotel itself I find quiet and peaceful. The people I have encountered on my stays have been warm and welcoming. The rooms are super clean and the beds and pillows I find comfy. The hotel has a great vibe and I find it comforting to come back to after a busy NYC day. An awesome boutique hotel!

My wife and I greatly enjoyed our stay at this 10th Avenue location in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood. We were in town for a wedding, and our experience found this boutique hotel a real pleasure. Distinct, comfortable, and feeling very much an organic part of this upscale urban location, the Highline greets you with a fine outside courtyard, perfect for coffee and socializing in good weather. Once inside, a low-key friendly check-in process introduces you to their personable staff. In the best sense of the word, this hotel has a casual (but professional) tone that makes for a nice decompression from the busy dynamics of Manhattan. 'Warm and cozy' are two words that come to mind. Is this a shiny, high-tech, officious wham-bam experience? Hardly. I do know I've never slept in a hotel bed as comfortable as the one in our room. Ever. The weekend we stayed there was a sweet Dog Parade/Halloween morning event that saw both local toddlers, parents, and doggies in their best Halloween finery(I wish coming back in the next life as a pampered canine living in Chelsea). If you want a comfortable alternative to larger, busier, formal toned places, in a neighborhood made for visiting , The Highline gets my 5 star review.

We LOVE The High Line Hotel. We have stayed here a few times now and never want to go home! The staff are second to none, the ambience of the hotel is perfect. It's a great chill-out space away from the busy day. The Chelsea area is gorgeous - perfect location. The rooms are so stylish, quirky and luxury. The beds are the comfiest beds in the world (I'm convinced!) - you will not have trouble sleeping here!! Visit the coffee bar in the day and the cocktail bar at night - Mike will serve you some killer drinks! Aaaannd... if you love dogs, this is the hotel for you. Thank you for having us - we hope to stay again.

Didn't expect the hotel to be so cute and charming, even done up for Halloween with pumpkins and twinkle lights. Pretty courtyard, cozy lobby with a cafe bar for coffee in the morning and drinks in the evening. Old manual typewriters sit on the lobby coffee tables, which you should use to bust out an impromptu poem. Beds were cozy, the room was clean and nicely decorated, and the shower was strong. Each room is different. Wooden floors creaked in places, which you could hear occasionally from room to room, but that only added to the charm for us. They have bikes you can borrow, and the hotel is only a block or two from the Greenway bike trail, which is amaze-balls. Runs all up and down and around he revitalized Manhattan riverfront (both rivers!).The staff couldn't have been sweeter or more helpful, from recommendations to bike borrowing to a friendly smile. Extra special appreciation goes out to Emily, Tidi, Joan (jo-ahn'), and Christian.Only a few blocks from Chelsea Market, and right next to the High Line trail. A couple of spots we loved were the Cookshop right next door and Bathtub Gin (which is set up like a speakeasy, so enter at the address and don't try to look for a sign). Wanted to hit the Empire Diner but ran out of time. Also bummed we ran out of time to hit the Sullivan Street Bakery. Other trip highlights: Nix restaurant (vegetarian) in the East Village, Palma in Greenwich, Osteria 57, Becco, and a tour of a small, indoor vertical farm (the future, people!!!) that grows microgreens called Farm.One in Tribeca. And oh my sweet lord, Tacombi Mexican restaurant just west of Washington Square Park.

Dark room, dark bathroom, old uncomfortable furniture, can hear overhead noise in particular, overall noisy. Refrigerator has no room for personal items; your stuck with expensive minibar. No room service. No coffee maker. Impersonal. The lobby has so much public traffic of people purchasing coffee and using their outdoor spaces, that guests are overlooked.

The room was always filled with smell of toilet (a.k.a pepper mint).The hotel's ambiance was so great and felt about the history of the High Line.Internet connection is healthy but all room lamp is not controllable by the wall switch.

Great location with "greenspace" on both sides of the hotel that felt like a little oasis in the city.Loved the Intelligentsia bar in the lobby and the patio bar out front.The courtyard views out the back were a nice treat.

Lovely aesthetic in outdoor space and indoor public area as noted elsewhere (though close very early if hotel guest and no room service) this review is for standard rooms (e.g. 57 and 37 1/2 etc) -- worst hotel experience in over 30 years of staying in nyc hotels since I lived here. Rooms were tiny (closet was a nasty garment rack just inside the door, bathroom size of powder room with no counter space), no seating outside of a chair at the desk, no dresser, furniture stained. Requests seemed to go into a black hole -- an acknowledged request via email was not executed so staff thought it a good idea to wake us up the morning AFTER we had checked in -- at dawn our time (6am - they knew we were coming from west coast) to ask about unanswered request. Beyond absurd. Never again. Except a drink during daylight hours and if you have a pet they love that FYI.

The Hotel is attractive looking, but the quality of the food and drinks at Ingo's is poor. The rooms very wildly, in particular the High Line suites are not all the same, and some do not have the facilities mentioned in the description (at least room 5 does not meet the description) . Some are attractive and worth it (room 3) others are actually worse than a regular room at nearly twice the price (room 5)

This place is amazing. The staff are superlatively trained. They are super-helpful and friendly. The rooms are beautiful and comfortable. As is true with EVERY hotel in Chelsea, the rooms are on the small side, but the way they've been decorated makes these smaller spaces work really well. I didn't feel claustrophobic or penned in the way I have in others. They have beautiful, eclectic furnishings and a gorgeous sense of design. The linens were spectacular, and the bed was crazy-comfortable. The entire place is really dog-friendly: treats in the lobby, a huge garden, and an onsite bar that has a "yappy hour" where you can order your dog a bowl of non-alcoholic ale! Plus, the coffee bar is stellar, and I met more "real" people and their doggies in one hour reading in the lobby than I ever have in all of my combined visits to The Big Apple. If you like big, corporate, impersonal hotels where you can hide, this won't be your place. However, if you like boutique hotels, if you prize living in a world of beautiful design, if you want your dog to come to the city with you and actually enjoy the experience, and if you like warm interactions with lovely human beings, this is your place.

A hotel that is full of character and interest. In a great location very close to the High Line and Chelsea Market.Very well furnished room with one of the most comfortable beds I’ve ever slept in - had amazing quality sleep.Good choice of restaurants nearby, so lack of hotel restaurant and room service didn’t matter.Room had the biggest “minibar” - almost like a full scale bar!Also very convenient to be walking distance to Sleep No More.

I have stayed in dozens of hotels in NYC, but this was a first for me at The High Line Hotel. It is great. Unique. Very hip, but with absolute class. Great service. Nice people. I would recommend it highly.

Loved this hotel overall. It is a very beautiful old property at a great location in Chelsea. The rooms are big and the staff is very helpful and friendly. Hotel is like a neighborhood cafe where people come to hang out usually with their dogs as it is super pet friendly. Only comment is the lights are all very dim around the hotel and in the rooms, but probably part of the ambience.

Chelsea is one of my favorite NYC neighborhoods, so the Highline Hotel is a welcome hub. Staff are exceptionally helpful and welcoming. Neighborhood bistros are fun to sample and staff share the mission of the Highline Hotel staff to make visitors feel welcome.

Having recently moved out of the city, we've tried several hotels on return trips to get the same neighborhood feel we enjoyed as longtime residents of downtown Manhattan. The Highline Hotel felt like having our own apartment in the city again - this time with outstanding service. Christian made our stay exceptional! Thank you!

great place - adorable ambiance, well thought-out refurbishment of roomsno front desk (check in at a PoS station by coffee bar), no clocks in room, housekeeping lacked a bit during my staycan use the highline to get to google nyc officeno onsite food, ice or gymroom could have used one more lampwifi, room size, and hotel patio were amazing

A big thanks to Christian and ALL the staff for making my wife’s birthday weekend so memorable. It’s a great place to just hang and it’s location is perfect to explore Chelsea and the Meat packing district. Grab a coffee and delicious jam donut from the cafe in the foyer and go for a lazy stroll along the high line!

Loved it! Would definitely suggest staying here. Upon arrival we contemplating just staying in the room instead of going out because they’re so comfy. Super cute, too! Great location for NYC, at least for first timers.

I was traveling for a business event and this was the closest hotel to the event. I have always passed on this hotel due to the cost, but this time I decided to go for it and was so glad that I did. The staff was welcoming and helpful. The bed was extremely comfortable with nice cool sheets. I loved the vintage-ish decor. This was the quietest and most relaxing hotel room that I have ever had in Manhattan.

great staff but need a big fresh clean- curtains rugs were really unappealing and looked old and not clean.we took room 36 so by the courtyard nice and quiet you can hear upstairs guests walking back and forth and trash in early AM.bathroom i nice and clean for a king room.

The bedroom and bathrooms were too dark, even with curtains open. The furniture was crummy, but the beds were comfortable. The sheets and towels were clean. The receptionists were sharp and excellent. The location was excellent .

We stayed in room 12 which was right about the cool coffee shop in the lobby and so was worried it would be loud but it was not. The king sized bed was incredibly comfortable and the room while small was very efficient.I loved the location and told my husband this will be our new hotel when visiting our daughter in Manhattan.

Loved staying at this quirky hotel in a nice part of Chelsea. Dog friendly / no, it positively encourages wet noses. Nice room with all amenities including mules and robe. Friendly staff operate from a single Apple MacBook Air to check in/out but manage admirably

We loved this hotel, wished we could stay longer! We are NYers and needed to be out of our apt for the day for work to be completed. The High Line Hotel is on a beautiful, historical street, be sure to wander the neighborhood. We took a lovely bike ride on their complimentary bikes on the river in the morning and when a downpour came and drenched us... we laughed like children the whole way back to the hotel. We accidentally left a valuable watch in the room and the staff found it and held on to it for us.Lovely customer service. Thank you.

The Highline is special. It’s physically lovely - inspired really. Beautiful outdoor spaces and a cozy lobby. High quality Intelligentsia coffee every morning Is an amazing way to start the day. The property and excellent staff make you feel welcomed and supported during your stay. I stayed at the Highline in their first month after opening. I have great memories of that trip too. I travel so much and it’s rare that a place stands out anymore. The Highline is one of those places that makes me inspired and energized about being on the road. The staff, the visionary art and warm atmosphere make the Highline an absolute standout. Special thanks to Christian at the front desk who made me feel welcome every day.

We stayed in this hotel for 6 nights in September 2019 and although I would say the decor and location of the hotel was excellent I found the experience to be sub standard.Considering the 6 night stay cost me in excess of $2000 there was no breakfast put on by the hotel and any coffee wanted in the morning had to be purchased downstairs for $5 per cup. Added to which the coffee shop was not open early so I had to walk round the block to purchase a cup from a take away.At the least I would have liked coffee making facilities in the room considering the cost of the accommodation. Also soon after checking in I had a hold of $900 put on my credit card for mini bar and damages. Despite asking for the minibar to be removed from my room I wAs told the hold would still stay which I find extortionate especially considering the $2000 I had already paid in full for the hotel and not to mention other expenses that I needed to pay with my credit card.. on balance I would not stay here again...

The room was big, bathroom was small and I'm over the old, tired furniture look. It just looks old, tired and dirty. The hotel is very dark and reminiscent of the NYC housing apartment building I grew up in. I know that the decor was supposed to be part of the "charm", including the old school elevator (beware if you're claustrophobic!), but it didn't work for me. Service was meh, at best. Delivered very little for the price.

We were walking the High Line and saw this hotel all lit up wit its fairy lights etc. A group of us walked in and we were warmly welcomed and shown to a table in the garden area. The drinks waiter was very friendly and accommodating and ensured we were catered for with drinks and any questions we had.Great area with all the garden set up and the big red bus. Lovely setting and fantastic night out.

y wife and I traveled in for business and then stayed over the weekend. In the past few times, we stayed near Broadway or some of the more tourist locations. The High Line Hotel is located in an area called Chelsea, located on the east side of Manhattan, just north of West Village. The location turned out to feel similar to my travels to some of my European trips.Located only blocks from Hudson River, I found myself strolling "quieter" streets of New York, having a nice breakfast at several local cafes and mingling with the locals at a beer garden just down the road at night.The Hotel offers free guest passes to the fitness center at Chelsea Harbor, which was an experience in its own! I had a nice walk to the fitness center early in the morning and found top of line fitness equipment in a HUGE facility. Later, we walked across to the High Line Park, which is almost like being in a different location all together.The hotel decor is very nice and the coffee shop on the first floor is a popular place among locals. Always full of people inside and out. The rooms were large compared to other hotels in New York. Sleep was peaceful and the beds were really comfortable. It is going to be hard staying anywhere else when visiting New York in the future.

No parking, find your own on the street (with all the alternate side issues) or find a garage. There is one across the street but i'm told they don't always have space (they did for us). We would have been happier if they warned us of this on their website, where there is no mention one way or the other. The receptionist was rather cool on this issue, noting she would have assumed there is no parking if the website didn't specifically state having it.Perhaps she would, thinking like a New Yorker working in a hotel. Being from out of town we had different assumptions. We really do like the hotel, however, and will go back.

First time staying here and chose the hotel because it was five blocks from the office. Loved my stay!! Amazing service! Comfy beds! Great water pressure and bathroom products. The staff remembered my name every day and went above and beyond to make my stay perfect. Thank you!!

Just returned from 2 nights in Manhattan. A getaway stay-cation. Our room on top floor. Though quiet as faced rear courtyard claustrophobic in feeling as small gothic windows (not large as described) with sloping ceiling. Dirty appearing ripped area rug that one couldn't even give away at a garage sale. Comfortable bed ruined by sheets overstarched or not washed with sufficient fabric softener producing a rough, scratchy feeling not conducive for sleep. Took air conditioner all night to finally cool down to comfortable temperature however air still felt humid. Dark bathroom with insufficient wattage. Yes nice to have good coffee bar in lobby and outdoor seating in front of building with bar and courtyard seating in back to eat breakfast (no breakfast restaurant). And stairway to High Line park across the street. But probably won't stay here again. And definitely not in room 56.

After a disastrous check in with an Airbnb apartment, I used the Hotel Tonight app to find a place to lay my weary head. The High Line Hotel popped up and I went right over. Immediately changed my reservation to two nights. So glad I did. Very spacious room, extremely well curated decor that did not in any way appear to be trying too hard. (Lots of that around the city.) All of the staff I encountered were genuinely happy to help. And the shot of burbon suggested by the barkeep was exactly what I needed after a hot, busy day running around town. I’ll always check for a room here first.

Outside bar was cosy, but please be more upfront if you charge 13USD for a bottle of still water. Waiter was not clear at all about this. No need for these kind unpleasant surprises. Your staff is missing out on deserved tips because of this, looks like this hotel/bar doesn’t need this kind of shady upselling.

Wonderful service and great atmosphere! Christian was extremely helpful with all aspects of the stay. Recommended to my partner. Is now working to secure space for L'Oreal senior managers meeting, including rooms and conference space!

The high line hotel is a nostalgic trip to the 1950's when you enter the guestroom. Its charm is so warm and relaxing it blends the modern conveniences very nicely. I would recommend this hotel to my friends and family.
"Chique" pricey boutique hotel in old Episcopal Seminary well located near Chelsea Piers and walking distance to new Hudson Yards and 34St shopping.No restaurant in hotel.A charming, acquired taste.

We had a wonderful time. Emily, who checked us in, was extremely helpful. She assisted us in getting to our cruise that evening. Also, I had mentioned it was our anniversary, and we were so touched that, when we got back to the room that night, there was a bottle of champagne waiting for us along with a lovely note. So thoughtful! Thank you for making our stay so special.

I loved everything from the tasteful decor to the quirky books in the room. Lots of good restaurants and bars in walking distance with the hotel being this charming, lovely bit of old manhattan. Def coming here again.

We absolutely loved the High Line Hotel, everything! Firstly the iconic old seminary is fascinating, beautiful architecturally and full of interesting nooks and crannies. The furnishings are what one would search out at brocantes to furnish one’s own home. AND the biggest plus are the dogs! all the neighbourhood dogs head for the High Line, they know where the dog action is!

My wife lost her ring during our stay and the hotel staff was super helpful. Excellent room and location near fun things in Chelsea, including Highline; Hudson Yards; Chelsea Market; and Starbucks Reserve. Highest recommendation!

The vibe at this hotel is simply amazing! Great city location bustling with activity but still feels quiet and relaxed. Staff rocks and I will definately be back on my next visit to the city. Well done High Line!

I stayed in a standard king room. Everything was very nicely decorated, clean, and comfortable. Great for a romantic evening. I will definitely be staying here again, and will recommend to all my friends and family.

Great casual and fun atmosphere & great location! Love the history of the hotel and the proximity to the High Line, Chelsea Yards, Chelsea Market, great restaurants, museums and the Starbucks Roastery.

Lovely hotel, in a nice part of the city. Close to Chelsea Market and lot's of nice bars and restaurants. Clean rooms, friendly staff. Cafe in the lobby that turns into a cocktail bar in the evening. Very much enjoyed the week I stayed there.

Great location with a hipster vibe. We were comfortable in the room and slept well. Pets are welcomed with open arms. Minus one star because the lobby is so small and was packed with people on their computers & phones at times. Lots of outside seating for guest. The room was clean and basic but very stylish and spacious. PROS: location  Fast internet  Spacious room Good shower pressure  Service  Pet friendly CONS: Very small lobby area

I have long loved this gem of a hotel hidden in Chelsea, and have stayed here a number of times. It has such a wonderful, different feel, like an old friend’s home. The rooms are large, the beds are comfortable, and although there is no room service or food, there is an excellent espresso/coffee bar in the lobby. The service is friendly and warm. The hotel’s charm is in large part due to the shabby chic decor. But of late, the chic has been giving way to shabby, and it does need some work. The frayed stair carpet off the lobby is now in tatters so that you almost trip on it, and the oriental rug in our room was similar. The door to our room stuck so much that a Herculean effort was needed to push it open, and my wife couldn’t do it. A little sanding would easily solve the problem. I will definitely return, but I do wish they would devote a little to stemming the deterioration.

But the staff is polite. Hopefully the room is nice. I have stayed previously, thought it was nice. Comfortable. I arrived early, planning just to leave my bag and go on to my plans. They said it would just be a short while, so i thought i would freshen up a bit. Hot in nyc today. Not so pleased that they could not find my reservation and then kept me waiting. Only had one free afternoon. If they had told me it would be such a long wait, i would have gone ahead to see the things I had planned. As it ended up, they just kept saying a few more minutes, gave a steady stream of guests their rooms, and let me sit. Maybe it was because i used Booking.com and did not book directly through the hotel?

Lobby is primarily for neighborhood residents and cafe users. Had to wait there while room was getting ready. Many dogs, all seemed well trained.Room is purposely old fashioned including breaking wooden floors. At first was concerned primarily about noise and comfort but it was dead quiet despite definitely having neighbors. Had two queen beds and one was perfect the other had a mattress that needed work. Shower pressure is awesome. Couldn’t figure out how to drain the sink. Plenty of space in this room considering it is Manhattan.

This is my first choice of hotels when visiting NYC/Chelsea....charming, well-located, great coffee bar and cocktails. The beds are plush and comfortable, room was more than adequate. Staff is welcoming!

The High Line Hotel offers that bespoke original New York Getaway. From hip coffee to sexy cocktails, experience the real West Side like a local. The rooms are stylish, comfortable and quiet. The staff are first class and couldn’t be more accommodating. Located feet from the High Line and a short walk to the Village, Chelsea market or the pier . Near enough to the tourists but still offers a real feel for what local life is like.

Great staff and love the downstairs lounge (very hipster vibe). Christian was very helpful and everyone there was a pleasure to speak to every day. You can't beat the location as well - walking distance to so many great restaurants and shops.

I had high hopes for this hotel but in retrospect I honestly would have preferred a Holiday Inn Express. It was bizarrely uncomfortable physically and interpersonally. I arrived when a magic show (?) was getting out in the tiny lobby so it was essentially as busy as Times Square at rush hour. No one helped me get my bag inside and I had to wander around getting buttressed by the sea of magic show (??) attendees before someone realized I was trying to check in. At that point the bellman took my bag and had me sit on a couch, where I waited in a chaotic rush of people until someone who worked there finally arrived to check me in. She was distracted and not terribly nice, mainly concerned about telling me what the hotel does not have (food, room service: no; magic show: yes (???)). When I called down later to ask if they would let a delivery guy bring takeout to my room (a fair question, i thought, since the tiny elevator requires key-card access) the front desk snapped at me that they don't have room service. (Which, yes, I know, that is why I am ordering takeout to my hotel room after a 12 hour travel day at 10pm, thanks SO MUCH for your help). Which is a long of saying: frictive, claustrophobic atmosphere, where you are made to feel like a problem. Not a good vibe from a hotel that seems to mainly offer vibe as its primary amenity.During the daytime the lobby turns into an Intelligentsia, and since it is tiny, it is just as rammed as when the magic show (????) is happening, plus full of dogs, one of which I tripped over trying to get up to my room. The front patio was closed for some reason, the back patio is tiny, the bar closes at 1030, there is no restaurant aside from the coffee shop. Our room was fine, deliberately shabby, kind of like if you stayed at the clean, bland guest room in your rich friend's parent's pied-a-terre, except they would at least have a kitchen and their living room would not be filled with dogs and a magic show (?????)If this hotel were not charging $500 a night I would be more tolerant of its "quirks" but it is actively unpleasant getting in and out of, there is no lobbyish space to unwind, and they could be a lot more charming or at least less confrontational about offering zero percent of the basics i could get with a smile at the denver airport courtyard marriott. but i hear the magic show (???????) is just great.

When we arrived it was raining and the tiny lobby was filled with people and dogs. There is a small bar there for eating and drinking. Reminded me of the Algonquin Hotel but smaller. I was told they are interesting people from the neighborhood who gather there to socialize and use their wi-fi. Our King room was delightful. A throw back to a more formal time. Beautifully appointed with things from years ago. Black dial phone, king bed, oriental rugs and a fabulous huge bathroom that had been updated for modern times. We loved the place and were greeted by the friendly Rose who mans the check-in desk. We stored our luggage before our room was ready and stored it again when we left since we planned on spending the whole day on the Highline, Chelsea Market and the new Hudson Yards. Would love to stay here again when we are in town. When we left people were engaged with each other at the outside tables.

I remember walking past the hotel a few years ago and saying that on my next trip that I wanted to stay here - so this time I did. As I’ve visited New York a few times, touristy stuff wasn’t the plan this time so The High Line was the perfect location. Walking distance to Chelsea Market and Greenwich where there are so great places to eat and drink at. The bed was INCREDIBLE! We arrived at 11pm and check in was great. The service was also really good when we checked out. The room was nice. It was clean. It was pretty shabby chic. Overall it was good and the location definitely is great if you’re looking to explore NYC yourself to find what you stumble upon.

Lovely friendly hotel in the trendy Chelsea area of NYC.Staff very attentive, quirky coffee shop in the lobby, dog friendly too which is always a major positive Very convenient for The High LineHighly Recommend

If you have walked the High Line in Lower Manhattan you have probably seen the Hotel which is just east of the High Line between 20th and 21st. It is a in a striking building and is very convenient to many trendy Chelsea spots. It's a small boutique with an exceptionally friendly staff. They really made me feel welcome. The hotel does have some quirks. The Lobby is a coffee shop. The trendy decor is a version of shabby chic. The beds and bathrooms are nice but some of the rooms are pretty small. The elevator to my room was of a type I had not seen since staying at a 100 year old hotel in Rome. Overall though, I enjoyed my stay.

It was my husband's first time to NYC and we absolutely fell in love with the High Line. Staff was amazing and so was our room. The only confusion we had was when we were told two different times for checkout but it wasnt a big deal.

I love the Highline Hotel. It feels like a warm blanket wrapping around you. I love the coffee bar in the stylish lobby. I stay at The Highline for business and the location is perfect. The neighborhood is full of great restauarants and the Chelsea Market is right nearby.Love it!

I've been staying here since it opened, and love it more every time. All of the rooms are a little/lot different, with lots of old charm due to the building's history. I LOVE seeing dogs in the lobby and courtyard on my way in and out, and having the option of amazing coffee in the morning. There is no room service but it's New York - you can have everything delivered! It's right in front of the High Line park, and just a few blocks from Hudson Yards, Chelsea Market, etc., plus they have bicycles available, but the best to me is that I can walk to where I'm working. It's my home away from home.

My husband and I stayed here when it first opened on a date and now we come back for our Aniversary! It’s a charming hotel with an eclectic feel! Nice beds great service and charm abounds! Plus they love our pooch that goes everywhere with us! The patios are beautiful, service and location are great as well lots of great things to say about The High Line!

I travel to New York once every couple of months, so I've stayed in a LOT of hotels. A lot of great ones, too, but none has had the allure or the unique style of the High Line Hotel. It's my favorite place to stay in the city, to the degree that it became a prominent location in my novel "Ghosts of Gotham." Excellent service, vintage comfort, it's a winner.The location is top-notch, too. You're within walking distance of all the charms of Chelsea; good food, plenty to see and do, and a great home base for excursions into the rest of the city.

Daniel Arias was extremely helpful to us during our 2 night stay at The High Line Hotel. He addressed any and all concerns that we had and was extremely thorough in following up with us. The High Line Hotel is in a great location and very quaint

The High Line Hotel brings a sensible charm to a city stay. In the morning, the hotel lobby feels like a friendly neighborhood hangout, with old friends stopping by to say hello. The location is perfect for a Chelsea / West Village visit. If you want a hyper-hip New York experience, this isn't it. But if you want a base while you temporarily make New York your home, you won't be disappointed.

Great atmosphere, very cosy, great service! We have our son living in your neighbourhood, and, while there are many hotel options, we will certainly keep coming back to yours. On our last stay, we forgot our passports in the rooms safe, and were most happy to have you retrieve them for us. Thank you!

Check into this gem and ask for Christian. He will go above and beyond to take excellent care of you! He made sure that we had a quiet room with everything that we needed. Don’t miss The Enigmatist show!

We've been meaning to stay at The High Line Hotel ever since we ducked in for a coffee several years ago. The hotel is in a repurposed religious seminary, occupying a magnificant old building. Our room was quite large by NYC standards, and featured a view of the quiet courtyard at the rear of the building. Everything is done in dark wood tones, especially the lobby, which is luxurious, warm and welcoming. The hotel lobby, and its espresso bar, appear to be a meeting point for the community (and their dogs!). It helped us feel like we were part of the community and not just tourists passing through. We found the hotel to be well situated near the High Line itself (well, obviously!), as well as Chelsea and the Meat Packing district. We walked down into the West Village quite easily. We are in NYC quite often, and we are always looking for hotels that are away from the traditional tourist areas. This fits the bill.We went in the winter, so we couldn't take advantage of their bicycle rental, but I definitely will take one out on the west side bike trail next time we are there in better weather. One heads up: there are short flights of stairs that join the various wings of the old building, so I would think that you should let them know ahead of time if you need an accessible room. The staff was really friendly, and the espresso bar in the lobby made really great bevvies.We will definitely be staying here again.

My husband and I had a delightful weekend. Wonderful room, gracious staff. Will definitely stay here on our next trip to NYC. Close to so many fabulous restaurants, too. A real gem! Coffee bar was cozy with delicious pastries. Will recommend to all my friends.

My husband and I stayed at the High Line for a special birthday (we had dinner in the Village). We treated another couple so we got to experience two rooms. I cannot overstate how delighted we were with every aspect of the hotel. First, the rooms were larger than expected and especially compared to usual boutique NY hotels that are less than $500 a night. Both the king room and queen rooms had a walk in closet and plenty of room to move around. Another amazing thing for an old quirky building: silence. We were on the 4th floor over a semi busy road and never heard traffic or even sirens. Lovely bath with good shower/water pressure. And (see other reviews) we had zero issues with HVAC. Next, the vibe. The coffee shop which turns into a bar at 6pm is happy and a mix of residents and locals and lots of dogs. We were there on a cold winter weekend, so it was a tad chilly, but it was warm in spirit. If you come in the summer (we have been for drinks) there is lovely outdoor space, all ok for dogs. The bartender gave us good ideas of where to go for an early breakfast, and the person doing the check-in/out was just warm and friendly. My husband said this is so not a “corporate” hotel! The coffee and pastries were first class and love the cocktails. Highly recommended! We are looking for the next excuse to spend the night at the High Line Hotel.

We had an amazing stay at The Highline! The staff were so kind and welcoming. The bed in the room was very comfortable. The room and bathroom were crisp and picturesque. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone looking to stay in Manhattan!

Our small NYC getaway was fantastic, and the property was superb as always. The High Line Hotel has always accommodated my staycations with top-notch service and hospitality. Our room was comfortable and embodies the look and feel of this quaint and charming neighborhood. Thank you again Nicholas D. for all of your attention, we had a fantastic stay!

This is our favorite hotel on the West Side of Manhattan. Great neighborhood, across the street from the High Line, a few blocks from the Hudson River Park, great restaurants, and super fun in the Spring with the outdoor bar. Best of all, it's an amazing hotel for dogs as you can hang in the coffee shop with all the neighborhood dogs. Be sure to request floors 3 or higher as it can get noisy on the ground & first floor.

The High Line Hotel is a true gem in a land of myriad boutique hotels! The check in was easy and very personable. The room was charming, full of light (room 59 feels like you’re staying in a Parisian garret with fantastic views north and west), and with just the right amount of style and comfort. The bed is to die for. Like literally I would die on this bed because I never wanted to get up. The bell staff made it easy to store bags after check out time so we could take a walk down the High Line, have a leisurely brunch and walk around the Whitney Museum.

Their coffee tastes amazing but this place is plagued by mice! I was there for a maximum of 20 minutes and saw 3! One of them even slid under a door (I’m assuming of guest room), I know this is Chelsea but I don’t think a coffee shop/hotel should have them running rampant like this. It’s a bit shocking. The rugs in the lobby also look very cruddy, I’m not sure how a hotel can claim to be a 4 star establishment when it looks this dingy. I will be leaving this same review under the coffee shop page.
